column1: Tarifa (Spanish pronunciation: [taˈɾifa]) is a Spanish municipality in the province of Cádiz
column2: Andalusia. Located at the southernmost end of the Iberian Peninsula
column3: it is primarily known as one of the world's most popular destinations for windsports. Tarifa lies on the Costa de la Luz ("coast of light") and across the Strait of Gibraltar facing Morocco.

column1: Tarifa has become a popular spot for northern Europeans to spend their summers.
Tarifa's unique wind conditions have made the beaches at Playa de Los Lances
column2: Valdevaqueros and Punta Paloma the most popular in Europe with windsurfers and kitesurfers. The funnel created by the Strait of Gibraltar creates a Venturi effect when either the Levante (Easterly wind from Africa) or Poniente (Westerly wind from the Atlantic) is blowing. These two winds prevail in Tarifa for over 300 days most years
column3: meaning Tarifa experiences exceptionally strong and consistent winds throughout the year. In addition
column4: localised thermal winds at locations such as Valdevaqueros mean that even when the prevailing wind is not strong it is often possible to windsurf and kite surf in Tarifa These unique wind conditions are also the reason Tarifa is dotted with countless wind turbines.Tarifa is located within the Intercontinental Mediterranean Biosphere Reserve
column5: a renowned place to watch migrating birds
column6: in particular the storks which cross the Straits of Gibraltar in spring and autumn. Also whale and dolphin watching can be done as there are several species living on the 14 kilometre-wide Straits

column1: == Transportation ==
There are regular ferry services connecting Tarifa with Tangier (40 minutes) and Ceuta (1 hour) from the ferry port.
Bus services run from the bus station on Calle Batalla de Salado. There are regular services between Tarifa and Algeciras
column2: about 20 km to the northeast
column3: and Seville about 200 km to the north. Direct buses also run to Málaga and Cádiz. In high summer a special kitesurfing bus runs along the A7 between Tarifa bus station and Camping Jardin de las Dunas
column4: stopping at popular hotels and campsites along the route.

column1: There is a taxi rank on the Avenida Andalucia. It is about 5 minutes walk from the bus station and is located just outside the Puerto de Jerez (the main entrance to the old town) at the junction of Avenida Andalucia and Calle Batalla de Salado.

Tarifa features a Mediterranean climate with Oceanic influences
column2: with warm summers and very mild winters. Rain is concentrated in winter
column3: with the summers being largely dry. Because of its proximity to the Atlantic Ocean
column4: precipitation in the wet period is quite high; monthly averages exceed 80mm in the two wettest months
column5: December and January. The influence of the ocean has the additional effect of creating a very small annual variation in temperature. Winters are warmer than inland Spain - and summers are cooler than most of the country - the average daily high in the hottest month
